document.docTitle: Triplectides aequalichelatus Malm & Johanson, 2008, new species
document.masterDocTitle: Description of eleven new Triplectides species (Trichoptera: Leptoceridae) from New Caledonia

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Description of eleven new Triplectides species (Trichoptera: Leptoceridae) from New Caledonia

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. This species is separated from many other New Caledonian
Triplectides
species by the presence of 4 hind tibial spurs. It is easily distinguished from
mariannae
,
nathaliae
and
wardi
by the longer mesal lobe of the inferior appendages and in the shape of tergum X. This species is easily separated from
dawnae
by shorter harpagones and mesal lobe of the inferior appendages. It shows great similarity to
smithi
but is generally larger, differs in the apical region of tergum X, and does not have the enlarged anterior foreleg claw.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 57–64.
Triplectides nathaliae ,
new species , male holotype. 57, forewing; 58, hind wing; 59, forewing anastomosis detail; 60, genitalia, lateral; 61, genitalia, dorsal; 62, genitalia, ventral; 63, phallus, lateral; 64, phallus, ventral.

FIGURES 65–72.
Triplectides mariannae ,
new species , male holotype. 65, forewing; 66, hind wing; 67, forewing anastomosis detail; 68, genitalia, lateral; 69, genitalia, dorsal; 70, genitalia, ventral; 71, phallus, lateral; 72, phallus, ventral.

FIGURES 73–80.
Triplectides dawnae
,
new species , male holotype. 73, forewing; 74, hind wing; 75, forewing anastomosis detail; 76, genitalia, lateral; 77, genitalia, dorsal; 78, genitalia, ventral; 79, phallus, lateral; 80, phallus, ventral.

FIGURES 81–88.
Triplectides aequalichelatus
,
new species , male holotype. 81, forewing; 82, hind wing; 83, forewing anastomosis detail; 84, genitalia, lateral; 85, genitalia, dorsal; 86, genitalia, ventral; 87, phallus, lateral; 88, phallus, ventral.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology. From Latin, aequalis – equal, and chela – claw; named for the equal-sized foreleg claws, in comparison to the similar species
T. smithi
, where the anterior claw is much larger than the posterior claw.
